Cross thanks David um first of all can you hear me back there excellent
somebody said no I'm sorry I'll talk as loudly as I possibly can so um first of
all I want to say it is such a thrill to be back here I have such unbelievably
sweet memories of being in the pit and being surrounded by 90 Brillion people
that could basically solve collectively any business problem that you throw their way it was a delicious feeling and
it was just great walking back on campus um I'm also very honored to to be part
of 50 years of women at Harvard Business School uh I graduated from John's
Hopkins University in 1974 and we were the first year they
admitted women so there were 50 women 1900 men and even though that was a
great ratio and it was great for my social life I have to tell you that being a Trailblazer particularly when
you're young it's tough so I'm very grateful for the Trailblazers that came
years ago and uh I I really appreciate that they what they went through to be
able to get us here where we are today so I thought I'd start and briefly tell you what the American Red Cross does and
I'm sure you're sitting there and you're thinking we all know what the American Red Cross does but even though one in
five people in the United States have been touched by the American Red Cross it's very unusual for me to meet anyone
that really understands the depth and breadth of all that we do so I know you know we collect blood in fact we Supply
40% of the nation's blood supply we ship between eight and 10 million units of
blood every single year and what is so fascinating about this is that every one
of those units was donated by somebody who opened up their veins and gave the
gift of life to a total stranger and our blood donors are just amazing it's one
thing to give time it's one thing to give money but when you're slicing open your veins that to me is The Ultimate
Gift and we're grateful for every single one of them um you know we respond to disasters and you've probably seen us on
TV in the evening news name a big disaster the Red Cross is there but what you probably don't realize is we respond
to 70,000 disasters every year and they're between eight and 10 of them right here
in the go the Boston area every single week and so these could range from super
storm Sandy to a single family house fire or a flood or a water man break and
if you're the victim of a house fire to you it's as catastrophic as Hurricane
Katrina and so we're there providing hope Comfort shelter food clothing and
the like so it's a very important part of our mission we also train people in first aid and CPR and babysitting
classes and Aquatics and lifeguarding and nurses assistance training about 7 million people every year take Red Cross
training and when I visit a city it's actually unusual for me to not have the
privilege of honoring some ordinary person that has done an Extraordinary
Deed to save someone's life so like the two grandparents who heard screams in
their backyard and found a four-year-old kid who had fallen through the ice in the lake in their backyard pulled this
kid out did CP on her for over 10 minutes when the Emergency Services guys
came they continued working on her and this kid was there when I gave them the award and she is absolutely alive and
well and flourishing as a result of their quick thinking I gave an award to an 11-year-old kid who took our
babysitting course she saved her three-year-old sister from choking while her parents were watching I mean it was
really quite an extraordinary story so it's a very important part of our mission and if you haven't taking CPR in
first aid this is my only commercial 27% of us are going to happen upon somebody
in cardiac arrest in our lifetime so if nothing else download our app it's
free um the part of our mission that most people don't know we do is what we do for the men and women in the armed
forces so every year since I've been at the Red Cross we have done between
250,000 and half a million emergency connections so we have volunt everywhere
the military is VA hospitals every military base and in theater so as we
speak I have volunteers station in Afghanistan and so these connections could be anything from I just talked to
my wife she's stationed in Iraq can you send a Red Cross volunteer to talk to her she doesn't sound good up to
including I was wandering around the Pentagon for an event someone spied my Red Cross Pin came up to me and said
ma'am I want to thank the Red Cross you brought me home in time to see my grandfather who before he passed away
from cancer and we will get the doctor's note the death certificate get the airline tickets we had him home in 24
hours so we're very proud of what we do for the men and women in the armed forces so needless to say when I got the
phone call to join the Red Cross it was the mission that attracted me but I have
to tell you when I walked through the door um we were kind of in Dire Straits I we were very Mission driven to a fault
so we had a $29 million operating deficit and when I turned to my CFO who
was there only a few weeks before I was he was hired I said how do you run a deficit how do we make payroll and he
said to me well we borrow money and this is in 2008 and the banks were so happy
to give anybody money you didn't even have to have a pathway as to how you were going to ever pay that money back
so on top of the $29 million operating deficit we had $612 million of debt we
had 720 chapters each one of them operated like separate Charities so each
one paid outside Auditors to do their books they had their own Finance systems their own HR systems their own payroll
systems um it was a wild wild west out there it really and truly was there were 4,000 bank accounts that we found as we
were peeling into all of this every one of these chapters had their own website so if you Google Red Cross we'd knock
each other out of the sort I mean you couldn't even find us there were so many websites so and the marketing messages
were absolutely all over the map and it we really didn't even know how to fund
raise I mean it it was It was kind of scary so I'm very proud to say that if
you fast forward to today that we're still fulfilling our mission probably as well if not better than we had in the
past we closed our deficit and we are slowly paying back our debt we've had a modest Surplus for the last 3 years we
Consolidated all of those back office functions um no easy feet because there were it challenges behind every single
one of them um we embrac social media so we are really trying to move the brand
to be more of a 21st century brand we have one website that was a big deal we
have one email system we had 720 of those and I you know people say to me
wow Gail you you did a turnar around this was everybody stepping up it was
the most remarkable example of teamwork I've ever experienced everybody sacrificed and everybody got us to the
Finish Line on this so when you ask the questions that I use my business Acumen to affect social change I mean the
simple answer to that is yes I mean every single one of I mean just think of every course you took in your MBA
program there was an element of it that we all needed to deploy at the American
Red Cross so we had to ensure a culture of fiscal responsibility we had to make
sure that people were accountable for results we had to make sure that the organization could move to a shared
services model instead of all this distribution um we had to do market research on why our donations were so
anemic um we had to set monster goals and and put initiatives in place to be
able to achieve them I mean just think of your your courses basically we kind of rattled through every single one of
them um and we had to change the governance we had to do Investments that were strategic uh it really was like
trying to get your MBA in about you know a couple of years so I can go into any
of these during Q&A but the the other thing that I will add is David asked me a very intriguing question which most
people don't ask me um but I usually volunteer it anyway and the question was well did you learn anything in the
nonprofit space that could be used in the for-profit space and there are two
things the first is to listen intensely there is no way we could have pulled
this off if we didn't listen we have 30,000 employees but we have half a million volunteers and when you say to
them this is the direction we're going in so everybody jump they do not say how high like I was used to in Corporate
America they say I don't think so convince me and you can't dock their pay
you know they're volunteers you can't give them a big bonus if they listen to you so the only tool you have is to
listen to take their input and to explain why the change is moving the way it is you've got to lead through
influence and the power of your ideas not through the power of your office and that's a skill that if you use in
Corporate America I would argue you could get people to change more rapidly and embrace change easily and you create
missionaries out there they all get the direction they all want to talk about it when when they understand it and then
the second thing thing is I also learned that you can lead with your heart as
well as your head and you know this is something when I was in Corporate America I was with AT&T I'd say people
calm down it's just long distance when I was with Fidelity I'd say people calm down we're just Gathering assets well
obviously at the Red Cross I can't say people calm down it's just you know we we're saving lives out there but having
said that I wish when I was back in corporate that I tapped into that innate
need that every human being has to be part of a higher purpose and frankly as
women we have to be careful we can't be cheesy or emotional when we lead because people will you know do one of those but
I do wish that I I said people this is not long distance we're connecting
people to the ones they love to we're connecting businesses to the information that they need when I was a Fidelity I
should have said this isn't Gathering assets we're making people's Financial dreams come true and I think I could
have been more of an inspirational leader back then if I just tapped into
that need to be part of a higher purpose so thank you you thanks so

why did we do that it's because we've all been there sometimes you have an immediate problem or you have one where

us some of us can't take on a full assignment so we were looking to match a
way to still contribute to our community and also be sensitive to our alums
that's been extremely successful I asked the question which is what are the big questions that most of

expansion marketing Communications and

contributions to all of those organizations we also did a couple of other things one which is we're now
doing board matching where our alums have an interest in particular topics or
or Community groups have a need for somebody and we're trying to to play a little bit of a Matchmaker that also has
been extremely successful so thank you all for already doing what you're doing
and just keep at it and encourage others to do so so the second thing I want to
mention is the role of being an investor that is predominantly what I do I'm a
private investor I've run some companies in the past made money which was my definition of success when I left
Harvard Business School and then contined to be an investor in this space
of of social Enterprise the monitor group I think actually does a pretty decent job of writing about this space
and some of the of the Publications that they have written about this talks about
that there's a lot of Buzz about this space but in fact it's very lumpy I'm an

ride we've and this is public information we've closed down three of the of the companies already and we have
several companies that the good news is is I think they're doing extremely well now why is being in this space from a
business perspective tough It's because if you're in the quote bottom of the
pyramid there's not a lot of existing capital or money for people to pay for
services so the margins of your products that are going into that space
frequently are very limited so you have to come up with Innovations in terms of
your distribution channels your marketing a way for people to pay all of
the things that everyone in this room takes for granted I I'm sure that Debra
could say that there are people in New York City who don't take those things for granted right and so whether it be

open what my personal view is that most groups who talk about being in the space
when it really comes to it are they really risk-takers and I would say most of them are not in fact what they really
want to do is to help accelerate some growth activity as versus really the
high-risk area The Innovation area and where I assure you there will be an
extraordinary percentage of failure and you have to be able to accept it embrace

area and if you want to read about it as I said I think the the some of the best work that's out there now is through the

about is an initiative here at the Harvard Business School as well as the Harvard School of Public
Health um one of the things that I found several years ago and I admit that I
couldn't have spelled the word Public Health had no idea what it was was that
when I was personally on my own journey to sort of say what's my next chapter going to look
like I became fascinated by the fact that the health area is such a large
percentage of expenditures it's a large expenditures of government and it's a
large expenditure for populations you can go from the highend which is India
71% of Health expenditures in India are out of people's pockets not the
government I'll come back to that in a minute in the United States the numbers are lower the numbers are around
47% of a expenditures have been out of pocket expenditures and the lowest one
is in the is in the UK pay at 16% so whatever you're talking about here it's
a huge amount of money and I'm part of that baby boomer profile it's not going
to go down it's only going to go up so what I came about with is the idea with
Howard Stevenson's help is to creating a collaboration here at the Harvard Business School and the Harvard School
of Public Health because what public health is really about is distribution it's taking ideas and it's getting it
out to the population and what we've done is really three things one which is we've created
an algorithm as a philanthropist because that's what the antari project is it's a
philanthropic activity here I said to myself where do I get the biggest bang
for the buck and do you know that in the medical world right now except for what we've created here people cannot answer
that question so we created a way to answer that question and the School of
Public Health has phenomenal data and what I'm very pleased to report is as of
a couple of weeks ago when our team went over to India we are working with the in Ministry of Health of India India is
going to go from about 1% of their GDP to something slightly under 3% of their
GDP and they asked us the question where do we spend the money we can answer that question and we
can identify and talk with them the choices they should
make we now are talking with other groups who have asked the same question help us identify where we should spend
our limited resources where do we get the biggest bang for the buck the two
other things that we're doing is of course in an educational institution it's about education so working with
various organizations we put together teams of students the students must
apply and we try to match the right skill set with the organization and we put together teams of students from the
business school from the School of Public Health we've even had a few Kennedy students sneak in and those
folks attack a problem now I will tell you over the something like 20 projects
we have done they are lumpy just like the investment world the reality of it
is is some of these organizations have real challenges their product doesn't work um their
organization isn't alone mind many of the things that Gail described we see
time and time again so again all of your skill sets we are using every day that
we're involved with this project and then again as an educational institution we of course create classes and cases
and help in terms of of getting this message out so I just want to end on on
two things one which is the lessons we've learned in this process and
Michael dud says it well he says to be effective in this space you have to have
best and that definition is what is is the best option for the
product economic what's the lowest cost for the
user s solidarity that is for all and t meaning
today like now the needs are today and he says to achieve this
you must have four other ingredients and he says it's S2
E2 and the S2 means scale and sustainability and the E2 means it has
to be efficient and it has to be effective it has to work I will give you
a preview of the three organizations that we've worked with this year we had a meeting yesterday and we're about to
tell one of those groups that their product doesn't work that is a problem so I'd like to just
end here um by saying that the dean five
eyes is really what this is all about and I know the dean is um has been with

if we all keep those metrics in mind and apply the heart Harvard Business School

infrastructure is collaboration infrastructure that um good good cities
are actually open networks that great cities like ours are attracting young workers who've grown up in a
collaboration economy so um if cities are collaboration places
and social change is going to happen in cities then it's going to have to be collaboration change so that was one
important point I want to make about my view on social change and social change in cities is that it's going to have to be collaboration change now the good
news the very good news in it relates to the question David's asked us to answer here today is that there's an amazing body of skills being built up in
businesses and in Business Schools to a certain extent they're tailor made for collaboration change just think about

strategy in the city of Boston in an office uh that's called the mayor's office of new Urban mechanics and it's an office that harnesses these skills

and around the globe so I'm very optimistic about that but I do worry um and that's because the dominant set of

all in fact uh the thing uh that is swamping in some cases uh government
government conferences and government journals and discussions right now are discussing on big data and big analytics
big companies uh are racing to try to sell us big systems um and they're

efficiency problems s they're not data problems problems like overhauling teacher contracts problems like thinking

own view is that this big change is going to require big engagement big collaboration big
trust so um it's something that even online companies are picking up you know
you look at a company like PepsiCo who a couple years ago spent $20 million to bring to build community around soda so
